Finding aid encoded by Manuscript Division staff

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Naval officer. Official and general correspondence, orders to duty, speech, article, and book file, memoranda, notes, printed material, photographs, and other papers relating primarily to King's activities as commander in chief of the United States Fleet and chief of naval operations during World War II.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Hungerford, Charles Frederick Algernon Portal, Viscount Portal of, 1893-1971--Correspondence.
King, Ernest Joseph, 1878-1956. Fleet Admiral King; a naval record. 1952.

corpname.part: United States. Joint Chiefs of Staff.
United States. Navy Department. Bureau of Aeronautics.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The papers of Ernest Joseph King were deposited in the Library of Congress in 1970, 1971, 1991, and 1998 by the Naval Historical Foundation and converted to a gift in 1998.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of Ernest Joseph King were arranged and described by Ruth S. Nicholson in 1971 and 1983. The finding aid was revised in 2011. An addition was processed and the finding aid revised in 2023 by Shandra Morehouse

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of Ernest Joseph King is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of Ernest Joseph King are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, Ernest Joseph King Papers, Naval Historical Foundation Collection, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Ernest Joseph King (1878-1956) extend chiefly from 1908 to his death in 1956, with the bulk of the material concentrated in the period 1936-1952. The collection consists of correspondence, subject files, memoranda, reports, orders, notes, and associated material organized in six series: Orders to Duty ; General Correspondence ; Subject File ; Speech, Article, and Book File ; Miscellany ; and 2023 Addition.

In the early years of his career, King was a submarine officer and from 1923 to 1926 he was commander of the Submarine Base in New London, Connecticut. There are several folders of material for this tour of duty, the most important of which documents the salvaging of the S-51 sunk off Block Island in September 1925. King was in charge of the successful raising of the S-51 , considered an outstanding accomplishment as it was generally thought that a submarine could not be raised from a depth of 125-130 feet of water. For this he was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal.

From submarines, King moved into aviation, qualifying as a naval pilot in 1927. In 1933 he was appointed chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, serving in that post until 1936, when he assumed command of the Aircraft Base and Aircraft Scouting Force in San Diego. King was promoted to vice admiral in 1938 and given command of all the aircraft carriers of the fleet. Files for this period of his life are a valuable source for studying the growth and development of military aviation.

King's papers for the World War II period and beyond are particularly significant. As commander in chief of the United States Fleet and chief of Naval Operations, Admiral King attended the Atlantic Charter Meeting (1941), the Quebec Conference (1943), the Cairo and Teheran Conferences (1943), and the Yalta Conference (1945). After the war, various individuals frequently sought information from him concerning these conferences and also about particular aspects of United States military and naval operations. Wherever possible, King was ready to cooperate and supply essential information. For example, he explained to Quentin James Reynolds and Robert E. Sherwood the origins of General James Harold Doolittle's 1942 air raid on Tokyo. Marine Corps General Merritt Austin Edson was interested in learning the story behind the Guadalcanal campaign. King responded with a letter of four pages that detailed his determined efforts, over strong opposition, to strike the Japanese in the Solomon Islands immediately after the Battle of Midway (June 1942). The letter also reveals the evolution of King's philosophy of Pacific strategy, beginning with his personal experiences at the Asiatic station during the early years of the century. Other correspondence in this vein is that of Walter Muir Whitehill, coauthor of Fleet Admiral King: A Naval Record (1952); Merritt Austin Edson for Pacific Island strategy; Bernard M. Baruch, on international control of atomic weapons; Ferdinand Eberstadt, on national security organization; and Richard S. Edwards, on matters relating to the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Material in the Subject File supplements much of this correspondence.

The Speech, Article, and Book File contain manuscript drafts of Fleet Admiral King and the rough notes for the book. Also in the file drafts and final copies of King's speeches and lectures. Material from his teaching days at Annapolis and items such as his thesis written at the Naval War College (1932) on “The Influence of the National Policy on the Strategy of a War” show the development of his thought in the field of world politics.

Important correspondents include Henry Harley Arnold, C. R. Atlee, Bernard M. Baruch, Omar Nelson Bradley, Oliver Lyttleton, Viscount Chandos, Mark W. Clark, Charles A. Edison, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Douglas Southall Freeman, William Frederick Halsey, Cordell Hull, Frank Knox, P. W. Litchfield, George C. Marshall, Louis Mountbatten, Earl Mountbatten of Burma, Chester W. Nimitz, Charles Frederick Algernon Portal, Viscount Portal of Hungerford, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Dorothy Thompson, Harry S. Truman, and Orville Wright.

The 2023 Addition includes a 1991 issue of Pull Together, a newsletter of the Naval Historical Foundation and the Naval History Center, with the article “Admiral King talks about Allied Strategy, July 1943,” and a declassified copy of King's 1947 speech “Some Aspects of the High Command in World War II.”

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series:

scopecontent.p: Letters received and copies of letters sent, telegrams, invitations, memoranda, and miscellaneous attachments.

arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically according to King's various commands and therein alphabetically by name of correspondent.

did.unittitle: Mountbatten of Burma, Louis Mountbatten, Earl
Mountbatten of Burma, Louis Mountbatten, Earl

scopecontent.p: Correspondence, memoranda, notes, photographs, and printed material.

College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va., 1942

Congratulatory messages, V-E and V-J days, 1945
Investigation of the national defense program, Canol Road Project, 1943-1946
Memoranda for the secretary of the navy, 1942-1944
Reunions of class of 1901, United States Naval Academy, Annapolis, Md., 1944-1947
Study of air logistic organization and procedure, 1944

scopecontent.p: Handwritten drafts, typescripts, printed copies, and other material including related correspondence.

arrangement.p: Arranged by type of writing with statements and writings of others filed at the end.

scopecontent.p: Printed matter, memorabilia, photographs, newspaper clippings, and other material.
